bachataV3CulturalHistoryTitle: The History of Bachata: From Dominican Republic to the World
bachataV3CulturalShort: Bachata was born in the Dominican Republic in the 1960s as music of popular neighborhoods. What started as music stigmatized by the upper classes became a global phenomenon.
bachataV3CulturalFull:
### From Dominican Neighborhoods to Dance Floors Around the World

Bachata has its roots in the Dominican Republic, where it was born in the 1960s as the music of humble neighborhoods. For decades it was marginalized by the upper classes, considered cantina music. Everything changed in the 1990s when artists like Juan Luis Guerra brought it into the international mainstream.

**"Bachata was born in the Dominican Republic (1960s): guitar music from popular neighborhoods that evolved to conquer the world."**

### The Sensual Bachata Revolution

In the 2000s, European dancers (especially in Spain) began fusing traditional bachata with elements of zouk, contemporary dance, and tango. Thus sensual bachata was born: a style that prioritizes body waves, intimate connection, and musical interpretation.

**"Sensual Bachata: modern evolution (2000s) that fuses Dominican bachata with zouk, contemporary, and tango. Prioritizes body waves, connection, and musicality."**

### Sensual Bachata vs Dominican Bachata

Traditional Dominican bachata is characterized by fast footwork, pronounced hip movements, and a more "street" style. Sensual bachata, on the other hand, emphasizes body movement, waves between dancers, dips, and a closer connection.

**"Key difference: Dominican = footwork and hips. Sensual = body waves, dips, and intimate connection."**

### Sensual Bachata in Barcelona

Barcelona has become one of the world epicenters of sensual bachata. Festivals, congresses, and an active community of dancers make the city a must-visit destination for dance lovers. At Farray's Center, we teach sensual bachata with internationally renowned instructors.

**"Farray's International Dance Center: sensual bachata with world champions, CID-UNESCO certification, +15,000 students trained."**
bachataV3FaqTitle: Frequently Asked Questions about Sensual Bachata
bachataV3FaqSubtitle: We answer your doubts so you can dance with confidence.
bachataV3FaqQ1: What is sensual bachata and how is it different from other bachata styles?
bachataV3FaqA1: Sensual bachata is a modern evolution of Dominican bachata that emphasizes body connection, musical interpretation and fluid movements like waves and dips. Unlike Dominican bachata (faster, with more footwork) or bachata fusion (mixed with other styles), sensual bachata focuses on couple connection and body expression. At Farray's we mainly teach sensual bachata, although we touch on elements of social bachata and bachata fusion in advanced classes.
bachataV3FaqQ2: Do I need a partner to learn bachata at Farray's?
bachataV3FaqA2: No, you don't need to come with a partner. In our classes we rotate partners constantly, which is actually better for learning because you learn to dance with different people. Many of our students come alone and that's how they meet friends and even partners.
bachataV3FaqQ3: What is the difference between sensual bachata and Dominican bachata?
bachataV3FaqA3: Dominican bachata is the original style, faster, with more footwork and closer to Dominican roots. Sensual bachata is a European evolution that focuses more on body connection, waves and dips. At Farray's we teach sensual bachata as the main style because it's the most danced at European socials, but we include Dominican technique elements to give you a solid foundation.
bachataV3FaqQ4: How long does it take to learn sensual bachata?
bachataV3FaqA4: In 3 months of regular classes you will be able to dance comfortably at any social. In 6 months you will feel like a completely different dancer. Of course, bachata is an art that you keep perfecting your whole life, but to enjoy socials, 3-6 months is enough.
bachataV3FaqQ5: What bachata level do I need to dance at social parties?
bachataV3FaqA5: With our basic level (about 3 months) you can already enjoy social bachata parties. You will know enough moves to have fun and connect with your partner. At socials you dance with all levels, so you will always find people to dance with.
bachataV3FaqQ6: Can I learn bachata without previous dance experience?
bachataV3FaqA6: Absolutely! Many of our students have never danced before. Our beginner class is designed specifically for people starting from zero. You don't need rhythm, experience or special abilities. We teach you everything.
bachataV3FaqQ7: What is bachata fusion and do you teach it at Farray's?
bachataV3FaqA7: Bachata fusion is a style that mixes bachata with elements of hip hop, contemporary, zouk and other dances. At Farray's our main focus is sensual bachata, but our advanced teachers include fusion elements in their choreographies. If you are specifically interested in fusion, ask about our masterclasses and special events.
bachataV3FaqQ8: What is Farray's bachata teaching method?
bachataV3FaqA8: Our method combines solid technique with fun and creative expression. We start with basics (rhythm, basic step, simple turns), progress to body connection and waves, and finally work on musicality and personal style. Our teachers are world champions who have adapted their knowledge for all levels.
bachataV3FaqQ9: Are there bachata social events at Farray's?
bachataV3FaqA9: Yes! We organize weekly practices and monthly socials where you can dance what you learn in class. We also organize trips to national and international bachata congresses. Our community is very active and you'll always have somewhere to dance.
bachataV3FaqQ10: How much do bachata classes cost in Barcelona?
bachataV3FaqA10: At Farray's we have flexible options: individual classes, monthly packages and unlimited passes. The welcome class is available so you can try without commitment. After that, prices start at ‚Ç¨40/month for 1 weekly class. Check our rates page for more details.

bachataV3CitableDefinicion: Sensual bachata is a dance style that evolved from Dominican bachata in Spain and Europe during the 2010s. It emphasizes body connection, waves and musical interpretation above footwork.
bachataV3CitableOrigen: Bachata originated in the Dominican Republic in the 1960s. It was initially considered music of the lower classes until Juan Luis Guerra's international success in the 1990s elevated its status globally.
bachataV3CitableSensualVsDominicana: Dominican bachata is faster with more footwork; sensual bachata is slower with more body movement and couple connection. Both styles are danced at international socials.
bachataV3CitableConexion: Couple connection in sensual bachata refers to the ability to communicate through the body, anticipating and responding to movements in synchrony with the music.
bachataV3CitableMetodologia: Farray's Center uses a progressive method with 4 levels: Beginner (0-3 months), Basic (3-6 months), Intermediate (6-18 months) and Advanced (+18 months).
bachataV3CitableFact1: An hour of dancing bachata burns between 300-400 calories, equivalent to 30 minutes of running but much more fun.
bachataV3CitableFact2: Farray's Center has Salsa LA world champion teachers (Mathias Font and Eugenia Trujillo) teaching sensual bachata.
bachataV3CitableFact3: Farray's Dance & Cultural Center is affiliated with CID-UNESCO, the International Dance Council recognized by UNESCO.

ssLandingWhyDesc3: We are part of the International Dance Council of UNESCO, a guarantee of quality and excellence in teaching.
ssLandingWhyDesc4: Just 2 minutes from Plaza Espa√±a metro in Barcelona. Easy access by public transport and nearby parking.
ssLandingTestimonialsTitle: What do those who have experienced it say?
ssLandingTestimonial1: Sexy Style classes have transformed how I see myself. I arrived feeling insecure and now I move with confidence. Yasmina creates a magical space.
ssLandingTestimonial2: I never thought I could feel so empowered dancing. The atmosphere is incredible and the teacher makes you feel comfortable from the first moment.
ssLandingTestimonial3: It's my moment of the week to connect with myself, feel sexy and enjoy. Plus, it's an incredible workout for the body!
ssLandingObjQ1: What if I've never danced Sexy Style or anything similar?
ssLandingObjA1: The welcome class is designed for absolute beginners. We start from scratch, with basic movements that anyone can do. No previous experience required.
ssLandingObjQ2: Will I feel uncomfortable with the sensual movements?
ssLandingObjA2: It's normal to feel a bit shy at first, but our environment is 100% judgment-free. We all start the same and the group energy helps you let go quickly.
ssLandingObjQ3: Do I need a specific body type?
ssLandingObjA3: Not at all! Sexy Style is for ALL bodies. What matters is connecting with yourself and enjoying the movement. Your body is already perfect for dancing.
ssLandingObjQ4: What clothes should I wear to class?
ssLandingObjA4: Comfortable clothes that allow you to move freely. You can come in heels if you feel comfortable, but it's not mandatory. Many students start with sneakers.
ssLandingFinalCTATitle: Your femininity deserves to shine. It's time to release it.
ssLandingFinalCTADesc: Book your welcome class now and discover why hundreds of women have found in Sexy Style their favorite way to express themselves.
ssLandingFinalCTAExtra: The next student who books might discover a new version of herself.
ssLandingFinalTrust: No cost ¬∑ No commitment ¬∑ Very limited spots

scLandingPageDescription: Try a FREE Cuban Salsa class with the Farray Method in Barcelona. Learn with Yunaisy Farray, creator of the method. Casino, Rueda, musicality and partner connection. CID-UNESCO Academy.
scLandingHeadline: Learn Cuban Salsa with the Farray Method
scLandingSubheadline: Discover the only proven method that teaches you to dance Casino as a couple from scratch. Perfect lead, authentic musicality and the Cuban joy that transforms your dancing.
scLandingTrustText: No cost ¬∑ No commitment ¬∑ Very limited spots

scLandingFestivalsText: And at the best Dance Festivals around the World
scLandingExperienceTitle: Ready to dance real Cuban Salsa?
scLandingExperienceDesc: Cuban Salsa is not just a dance: it's connection, joy and tradition. With the Farray Method you'll learn to lead or follow naturally, feel the rhythm in your body and enjoy every step. From day one you'll dance as a couple with real technique.
scLandingValueSubtitle: All this available for new students
scLandingValueItem2: Introduction to the Farray Method: lead and follow from day 1
scLandingValueItem3: Small group: limited spots each week

scLandingLimitedSpots: Spots fill up fast. If you want to secure your place, book now.
scLandingWhyTitle1: The Farray Method: unique in the world
scLandingWhyDesc1: Created by Yunaisy Farray, this method teaches you to lead/follow from the first class. You don't memorize steps: you understand the logic of Cuban Casino and dance with any partner.
scLandingWhyTitle2: Yunaisy Farray and Iroel Bastarreche: Cuban masters
scLandingWhyDesc2: Learn directly from dancers trained in Cuba with decades of experience. Their teaching combines professional technique with the authentic joy and flavor of Casino.
scLandingWhyDesc3: We are part of the International Dance Council of UNESCO, a guarantee of quality and excellence in teaching.
scLandingWhyDesc4: Just 2 minutes from Plaza Espa√±a metro in Barcelona. Easy access by public transport and nearby parking.
scLandingTestimonialsTitle: What do those who have lived it say?
scLandingTestimonial1: 5 stars and only because there aren't more. Spectacular, from the minute you step into reception, to the teachers, the quality and the good vibes.
scLandingTestimonial2: The Farray Method completely transformed my dancing. Now I lead with confidence and dance on time. After years stuck at other schools, here I finally understood what real Cuban salsa is.
scLandingTestimonial3: I always said I had two left feet. In 3 months I was dancing at my first party. Level 0 is pure magic.
scLandingObjQ1: What if I've never danced Cuban Salsa or any other dance?
scLandingObjA1: The Farray Method is designed precisely for absolute beginners. Our Level 0 teaches you the fundamentals step by step, without needing previous experience. In a few classes you'll be dancing as a couple.
scLandingObjQ2: Do I need to come with a dance partner?
scLandingObjA2: Not necessary. In class we rotate partners so you learn to dance with different people. This way you develop better technique and feel comfortable dancing with anyone at a party.
scLandingObjQ3: What's the difference between Cuban Salsa and other types of Salsa?
scLandingObjA3: Cuban Salsa (Casino) is danced in a circle with fluid and spontaneous movements. It is more social and fun than line salsa. The Farray Method teaches you the authentic Cuban essence, not a commercial version.
scLandingObjQ4: What should I wear to class?
scLandingObjA4: Comfortable clothes that allow you to move freely. Sneakers or shoes with smooth soles (avoid rubber soles that stick to the floor). You don't need special footwear to start.
scLandingVideoSubtitle: This is how Cuban Salsa is lived at Farray's
scLandingLocationAddress: Farray's International Dance Center - Calle Enten√ßa n¬∫ 100, 08015 Barcelona
scLandingFinalCTATitle: The Cuban rhythm is waiting for you. Do you dare to try it?
scLandingFinalCTADesc: Book your welcome class now and discover why thousands of students have chosen the Farray Method to learn Cuban Salsa in Barcelona.
scLandingFinalCTAExtra: First 10 to book this week: priority access to preferred schedule
scLandingFinalTrust: No cost ¬∑ No commitment ¬∑ Very limited spots

ctLandingPageDescription: Try a FREE Contemporary Dance class with Daniel Sen√© and Alejandro Mi√±oso in Barcelona. Floor technique, release, improvisation and body expression. No previous experience needed. CID-UNESCO Academy.
ctLandingHeadline: Discover Contemporary Dance and Connect with Your Body
ctLandingSubheadline: A class to explore fluid movement, floor technique and body expression. No previous experience needed.
ctLandingTrustText: No cost ¬∑ No commitment ¬∑ Very limited spots
ctLandingFestivalsText: And at the best Dance Festivals around the World
ctLandingExperienceDesc: Contemporary dance is freedom of expression, mind-body connection and fluid technique. In your first class you will discover a space where every movement tells a story, guided by teachers trained at the most prestigious dance schools in Cuba.
ctLandingValueItem2: Introduction to floor technique and release
ctLandingValueItem5: Access to private offer if you decide to sign up that day

ctLandingWhyTitle1: Lyrical Contemporary and Afro Contemporary (Cuban ENA Technique)
ctLandingWhyDesc1: Teachers trained at the prestigious National School of Art of Cuba. Explore from expressive lyrical to Afro Contemporary with African roots and elite Cuban technique.
ctLandingWhyTitle2: Progressive technique adapted to your level
ctLandingWhyDesc2: From beginner to advanced in Lyrical Contemporary, Floor & Flow and Afro Contemporary. Progress at your own pace with a methodology that respects your body and enhances your expression.
ctLandingWhyDesc3: We are an official center of the International Dance Council. Your training has international backing and access to official certifications.
ctLandingWhyDesc4: Rooms with professional linoleum floating floor, full-body mirrors and climate control. 5 minutes from Plaza Espa√±a and Sants Estaci√≥.
ctLandingTestimonialsTitle: What do those who have experienced it say?
ctLandingTestimonial1: Daniel's contemporary classes are incredible. They have helped me discover movements I didn't know my body could make. Plus, the atmosphere at the school is super welcoming.
ctLandingTestimonial2: I had never danced and Alejandro made me feel comfortable from the first moment. The style is challenging but very rewarding.
ctLandingTestimonial3: After years of doing yoga I was looking for something different. Lyrical contemporary has been a discovery. I love the mind-body connection and how tired I leave the classes.
ctLandingObjQ1: What if I've never done contemporary dance or have no previous training?
ctLandingObjA1: Perfect, we start from scratch. Beginner classes are specifically designed for people with no experience. We work on body awareness step by step, with accessible exercises that prepare you for more complex movements.
ctLandingObjQ2: Do I need flexibility or special physical condition?
ctLandingObjA2: No. Flexibility and strength develop with practice. Our teachers adapt the exercises to each body. What matters is the willingness to explore and enjoy movement.
ctLandingObjQ3: Is it very different from classical ballet or yoga?
ctLandingObjA3: Contemporary dance takes elements from both but adds freedom of expression and improvisation. It is less rigid than ballet and more dynamic than yoga. Many students come from both disciplines and find contemporary dance a perfect complement.
ctLandingObjQ4: What clothes and footwear do I need for class?
ctLandingObjA4: Comfortable clothes that allow wide movement (leggings, t-shirt). Contemporary is danced barefoot or with non-slip socks. You do not need to invest in anything special for your first class.
ctLandingFinalCTATitle: Your body has stories to tell. Time to express them.
ctLandingFinalCTADesc: Join hundreds of students who have discovered contemporary dance in Barcelona. Your first class is completely free.
ctLandingFinalTrust: No cost ¬∑ No commitment ¬∑ Very limited spots

btLandingPageDescription: Try a welcome classical ballet class in Barcelona. Teachers trained at the National School of Art of Cuba. Technique, posture and elegance for all levels.
btLandingHeadline: Discover the Elegance of Classical Ballet in Barcelona
btLandingSubheadline: Develop perfect posture, flexibility and grace with teachers trained at the prestigious National School of Art of Cuba. Your first class is completely free.

btLandingExperienceTitle: Ready to discover the elegance of ballet?
btLandingExperienceDesc: Classical ballet is the foundation of all dances. Develop strength, flexibility and impeccable posture while connecting with a centuries-old artistic tradition. Our teachers, trained at the National School of Art of Cuba, will guide you step by step.
btLandingValueItem2: Barre and center work adapted to your level
btLandingValueItem5: Access to private offer if you decide to join that day
btLandingOfferDesc: Welcome class spots are very limited each week. Book now to secure your place and begin your classical ballet training.
btLandingScheduleSubtitle: Classes available at Calle Enten√ßa n¬∫ 100, Barcelona
btLandingLimitedSpots: Each class has very limited spots to guarantee personalized attention
btLandingWhyTitle1: Teachers trained at the National School of Art of Cuba
btLandingWhyDesc1: Daniel Sen√© and Alejandro Mi√±oso combine demanding Cuban technique with adult-adapted pedagogy. Learn from professionals who have performed on international stages.
btLandingWhyDesc2: From absolute beginner to intermediate. Each exercise is designed for you to progress safely, respecting your body and developing real technique.
btLandingWhyDesc3: We are an official center of the International Dance Council. Your training has international backing and access to official certifications.
btLandingWhyDesc4: Rooms with professional floating floor, ballet barres, full-length mirrors and air conditioning. 2 minutes from Plaza Espa√±a Metro with free parking.
btLandingTestimonialsTitle: What do those who have experienced it say?
btLandingTestimonial1: I always wanted to do ballet but thought it was too late. With Daniel I found a perfect environment to learn. Cuban technique has something special, very musical and expressive.
btLandingTestimonial2: Alejandro's class surprised me. Very professional but approachable. He corrects me with care and I notice how my posture improves week by week.
btLandingTestimonial3: After years of pilates, ballet has been an incredible change. The discipline, the music, the elegance... I love coming to class.
btLandingObjQ1: What if I have never done ballet or have no prior training?
btLandingObjA1: Perfect, we start from scratch. Beginner classes are designed for adults with no experience. We work on basic positions, coordination and musicality step by step, without rushing.
btLandingObjQ2: Do I need a lot of flexibility or be in shape?
btLandingObjA2: No. Flexibility and strength develop with practice. Our teachers adapt the exercises to each body. What matters is consistency and willingness to learn.
btLandingObjQ3: Am I not too old to start ballet?
btLandingObjA3: It's never too late. Ballet for adults focuses on the benefits: posture, coordination, strength and artistic expression. We have students from 20 to 60 years old enjoying every class.
btLandingObjQ4: What clothes and footwear do I need for class?
btLandingObjA4: Comfortable, fitted clothing (leggings, leotard or fitted t-shirt). For the first class you can come with socks. Afterwards we recommend half-sole ballet slippers.
btLandingFinalCTATitle: The most elegant discipline in the world awaits you
btLandingFinalCTADesc: Join hundreds of students who have discovered classical ballet in Barcelona. Your first class is completely free.
btLandingFinalCTAExtra: First 10 to book this week: personalized orientation session included
btLandingFinalTrust: No cost ¬∑ No commitment ¬∑ Very limited spots

privacy_page_description: Privacy policy and data protection of Farray's Center. Information about how we process your personal data in accordance with GDPR.
privacy_hero_intro: Your privacy is important to us. In this Policy we explain what personal data we collect, what we use it for, who we share it with and what rights you have.
privacy_prevalence_clause: This Privacy Policy was originally drafted in Spanish. In case of discrepancy between translated versions and the Spanish version, the Spanish text shall prevail.
privacy_section1_intro: At Farray's Center, two distinct entities coexist. Depending on the service, the data controller may change:
privacy_section1_controller_a_title: A) Controller (Website, Merchandising and SL Services)
privacy_section1_controller_a_desc: The SL is the website owner and responsible for data processed for:
privacy_section1_controller_a_item3: Services provided by the SL (private sessions, corporate services, weddings, teambuilding, farewell parties and similar)
privacy_section1_controller_b_title: B) Controller (Sports Activities for Club Members)
privacy_section1_controller_b_desc: The Club is responsible for data processed for:
privacy_section1_controller_b_item3: Bookings and participation in sports activities
privacy_section1_controller_b_item4: Access control and associated administrative management
privacy_section1_note_text: The SL may provide support/marketing services to the Club. In such cases, the SL may process data on behalf of the Club as "data processor", when necessary and with the corresponding legal agreement.
privacy_section2_intro: Depending on how you interact with us, we may process:
privacy_section2_item1_text: name, surname, email, phone, and other data necessary to manage requests.
privacy_section2_item2_text: ID/Tax ID only when necessary (e.g. verification, billing, incidents).
privacy_section2_item4_text: member status, bookings, attendance, credits, incidents.
privacy_section2_item5_text: we do not store your complete card number. Payments are processed through secure gateways.
privacy_section2_item6_text: IP, browser/device, and cookie data according to your settings/consent.
privacy_section2_item7_text: only if there is consent for capture and use, or if properly informed and legally applicable.
privacy_section3_item3: Contracting services provided by the SL.
privacy_section3_item4: Club registration and bookings through management platform (for example, Momence).
privacy_section3_item5: Communications via email/phone/WhatsApp if you use them to manage a request or incident.
privacy_section4_intro: We process your data in accordance with GDPR and applicable Spanish regulations.
privacy_section4_sl_a: a) Responding to requests and contact
privacy_section4_sl_a_basis: Legal basis: consent and/or pre-contractual measures.
privacy_section4_sl_b_basis: Legal basis: contract performance and legal obligations.
privacy_section4_sl_c_desc: (private sessions, corporate, weddings, teambuilding, farewell parties, etc.).
privacy_section4_sl_c_basis: Legal basis: contract performance and legal obligations.
privacy_section4_sl_d_basis: Legal basis: consent (revocable at any time).
privacy_section4_club_a: a) Registration and member status management
privacy_section4_club_a_basis: Legal basis: associative/contractual relationship and legal obligations.
privacy_section4_club_b_basis: Legal basis: relationship performance and legitimate organizational interest.
privacy_section5_intro: We do not sell your data. We only share it when necessary to provide the service or due to legal obligation.
privacy_section5_provider2_text: Custom developed by Farray's Dance & Fitness SL.
privacy_section5_others_title: We may also communicate data to:
privacy_section5_others_item1: Public administrations, judges and courts, law enforcement, when there is a legal obligation.
privacy_section5_others_item2: Advisory/management, audit or legal/accounting support, when necessary and with confidentiality.
privacy_section6_intro: Some providers may process data outside the EEA (for example, USA). When this occurs, we will apply appropriate legal mechanisms:
privacy_section6_item2: Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) and additional measures when necessary.
privacy_section7_intro: We retain data only for the time necessary for the stated purposes and during the periods required by applicable regulations:
privacy_section7_item1_text: while management lasts and, afterwards, the time necessary to handle claims.
privacy_section7_item2_text: during the relationship and applicable legal periods (tax/accounting).
privacy_section7_item3_text: until you unsubscribe or withdraw consent.
privacy_section7_item4_text: while the member/user relationship lasts and according to legal/organizational periods and defense against claims.
privacy_section8_rights: access, rectification, erasure, objection, restriction and portability
privacy_section8_exercise_text: Write to {email} with subject "Data Protection ‚Äì Rights", indicating your request and, if necessary, a means of identity verification.
privacy_section8_complaint: You can also lodge a complaint with the {link} if you consider that the processing does not comply with regulations.
privacy_section9_text1: In Spain, consent-based processing of data from minors under 14 years of age is only lawful if consent from the holder of parental authority or guardianship is obtained.
privacy_section9_text2: If we detect data from minors without valid consent, we may cancel/limit registration and delete the data when appropriate.
privacy_section10_intro: During activities and events, images/videos may be captured for informational and/or promotional purposes.
privacy_section10_item1: The legal basis will be consent when applicable (and, for minors, that of the legal representative).
privacy_section10_item2: You can withdraw consent at any time by writing to {email}.
privacy_section10_item3: Withdrawal does not affect lawfully made uses, but does affect reasonably avoidable future uses (e.g. new publications).
privacy_section11_text: We apply reasonable technical and organizational measures to protect data. However, no system is 100% impenetrable.
privacy_section12_intro: We use technical cookies and, if you consent, analytics and advertising/remarketing cookies.
privacy_section12_text: Non-essential cookies are only activated according to your settings/consent in the banner or preferences panel. See the site {link} for more details.
privacy_section13_text: We may update this Policy due to legal or operational changes. The "Last updated" date indicates the current version.
cookies_page_description: Cookie policy of Farray's Center. Information about the cookies we use, their purpose and how to manage your preferences.
cookies_hero_intro: On this page we explain what cookies are, which ones we use on our website and how you can configure your preferences.
cookies_prevalence_clause: This Cookie Policy was originally drafted in Spanish. In case of discrepancy between translated versions and the Spanish version, the Spanish text shall prevail.
cookies_section1_text1: Cookies are small text files that are stored on your device (computer, tablet, mobile) when you visit a website. They allow the site to remember your actions and preferences over a period of time.
cookies_section1_text2: There are different types of cookies depending on their purpose: technical, analytics, advertising, etc. Some are strictly necessary for the site to function, while others require your prior consent.
cookies_section2_intro: The use of cookies in Spain is regulated by:
cookies_section2_lssi_text: (Law 34/2002, on Information Society Services): Requires informing the user and obtaining consent for non-essential cookies.
cookies_section2_rgpd_text: (General Data Protection Regulation): Requires consent to be free, informed, specific and unambiguous.
cookies_section2_lopdgdd_text: (Organic Law 3/2018): Adapts the GDPR to Spanish law.
cookies_section2_important_text: Essential cookies do not require consent, but do require information. Analytics and advertising cookies are only activated if you give your explicit consent.
cookies_section3_essential_text: Necessary for the basic functioning of the site. They do not collect personal information and cannot be disabled.
cookies_section3_analytics_text: Allow us to measure traffic and analyze user behavior to improve the site. Only activated with your consent.
cookies_section3_marketing_text: Allow displaying personalized ads and measuring campaign effectiveness. Only activated with your consent.
cookies_section3_functional_text: Enhance user experience with additional features such as embedded videos. Only activated with your consent.
cookies_section3_maps_text: If the site includes Google maps, cookies may be set for the service to function. Only activated with your consent.
cookies_purpose_video_stats: Registers an ID for video statistics
cookies_section4_intro: You can change your cookie preferences at any time:
cookies_section4_duration_text: Your cookie preferences are saved for 1 year. After that period, we will request your consent again.
cookies_section4_option1_text: Click the following button to open the settings panel and adjust which cookie categories you accept:
cookies_section4_option2_text: You can also configure your browser to block or delete cookies. Please note that this may affect site functionality.
cookies_section5_intro: Some of the third-party cookie providers mentioned in this policy are companies based outside the European Economic Area (EEA), mainly in the United States.
cookies_section5_google_text: (Analytics, YouTube, Maps): Operates under the EU-U.S. Data Privacy Framework and Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) approved by the European Commission.
cookies_section5_meta_text: (Facebook Pixel): Uses Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) to ensure an adequate level of protection.
cookies_section5_consent_note: These transfers are only made when the user has given consent for the corresponding cookie categories (analytics, marketing or functional).
cookies_section6_more_info: For more information about personal data processing, see our
cookies_section7_text: This Cookie Policy may be updated to reflect legal or technical changes. The "Last updated" date indicates the current version. We recommend reviewing it periodically.

cuerpofitWhatIsTitle: What is Body Conditioning and why do you need it?
cuerpofitWhatIsP1: Body conditioning or physical conditioning is comprehensive training designed specifically for the demands of dance. It combines functional strength exercises, active flexibility, joint mobility and core stability to create a stronger, more agile body resistant to injuries.
cuerpofitWhatIsP2: Unlike conventional fitness, body conditioning for dancers works on specific movement patterns of dance: extensions, jumps, turns, direction changes and floorwork. Each exercise is designed to improve your dance performance.
cuerpofitWhatIsP3: At Farray's Center we apply the Farray Method¬Æ to physical conditioning, integrating Pilates techniques, functional yoga, strength training and joint mobility into a cohesive system that transforms your body.
cuerpofitWhatIsP4: Whether you're a professional dancer looking to prevent injuries, an enthusiast wanting to improve your technique, or someone seeking complete training with a dance focus... body conditioning is for you.
cuerpofitWhatIsQuestionTitle: Do you want a body prepared to dance without limits?
cuerpofitWhatIsQuestionAnswer: Body conditioning is the invisible foundation of dance. A strong, flexible and resilient body allows you to execute any movement with safety and expressiveness.

cuerpofitCulturalHistoryTitle: The Science of Body Conditioning for Dancers
cuerpofitCulturalShort: Modern body conditioning for dancers integrates knowledge of biomechanics, exercise physiology and dance pedagogy to create specific training programs.
cuerpofitCulturalFull:
### History of Physical Conditioning in Dance

**Specific physical training for dancers has its roots in the classical ballet tradition.** Teachers like Agrippina Vaganova (1879-1951) already incorporated strengthening exercises into their methodologies, though in a less systematic way than today.

**"Pilates (Joseph Pilates, 1920s): originally developed to rehabilitate injured New York City Ballet dancers."**

### The Pilates Revolution

**Joseph Pilates developed his "Contrology" method working with New York City Ballet dancers in the 1940-60s.** George Balanchine and Martha Graham were pioneers in incorporating Pilates into their companies' training, establishing the foundation of what we now know as "cross-training" for dancers.

**"Gyrotonic (Julio Horvath, 1980s): three-dimensional training system created by a former dancer for dancers."**

### Modern Functional Training

**Eric Franklin (Franklin Method, 1994) revolutionized the field by integrating mental imagery with physical training.** His dynamic visualization techniques improve proprioception and neuromuscular control, essential elements for dancers.

**"Eric Franklin (1994): introduced neuroplasticity applied to dance training."**

### Science-Backed Benefits

Sports medicine studies applied to dance show that:
- Strength training reduces injuries in dancers by 50-70%
- Active flexibility is 40% more functional than passive flexibility for performance
- Core training improves balance and turn control by 35%
- Specific plyometrics increase jump height by 15-25%

### The Farray Method¬Æ in Body Conditioning

The Farray Method¬Æ integrates elements of Pilates, functional yoga, strength training and joint mobility into a system specifically designed for the demands of contemporary and urban dance. The key is working functional movement patterns, not isolated muscles.

cuerpofitFaqTitle: Frequently Asked Questions about Body Conditioning
cuerpofitFaqQ1: Do I need to be a dancer to do body conditioning?
cuerpofitFaqA1: It's not essential, although the class is designed with dance demands in mind. If you practice any type of dance (urban, Latin, contemporary, etc.), you'll benefit enormously. It's also ideal for athletes who want to improve flexibility and body control, or anyone seeking complete functional training.
cuerpofitFaqQ2: What's the difference between body conditioning and Pilates?
cuerpofitFaqA2: Body conditioning is broader and incorporates Pilates elements, but also functional yoga, bodyweight strength training, joint mobility and dance-specific exercises. Pilates focuses mainly on core and posture; body conditioning works the whole body with a focus on movement performance.
cuerpofitFaqQ3: What's the difference between body conditioning and stretching classes?
cuerpofitFaqA3: Stretching focuses on increasing passive and active flexibility. Body conditioning is more comprehensive: it works strength, endurance, mobility and flexibility. They're complementary: many students do both classes. Stretching to gain range of motion, body conditioning to strengthen it.
cuerpofitFaqQ4: Is it an intense class? Will I be exhausted?
cuerpofitFaqA4: The intensity is moderate-high but controlled. It's not HIIT or CrossFit. It's conscious strength and control work. You'll be tired but not destroyed. The class is designed so you can take other dance classes afterward without problem.
cuerpofitFaqQ5: What should I bring to class?
cuerpofitFaqA5: Comfortable workout clothes that allow wide movement (leggings, fitted t-shirt or top). Barefoot or with socks (no shoes). Small towel and water bottle. We provide the mats.
cuerpofitFaqQ6: Does it help prevent dance injuries?
cuerpofitFaqA6: Yes, it's one of the main objectives. Studies show that dancers with regular strength training have 50-70% fewer injuries. Body conditioning strengthens the most vulnerable areas (hips, knees, ankles, back) and corrects muscular imbalances.
cuerpofitFaqQ7: How much does the welcome class cost?
cuerpofitFaqA7: The welcome class costs 10‚Ç¨ and has no commitment. You can try any Monday at 7pm. If you like it, there are monthly passes from 40‚Ç¨. Check all prices at reception or on our website.
cuerpofitFaqQ8: Is there a contract or commitment?
cuerpofitFaqA8: No. Monthly passes without commitment. You can come and go as you please. We value your freedom and want you to come because you want to, not because you're tied to a contract.
cuerpofitFaqQ9: Can I combine body conditioning with other classes?
cuerpofitFaqA9: Yes, it's the ideal combination. We recommend: body conditioning (physical foundation) + your regular dance classes + optional stretching. Many students combine Monday body conditioning + Tuesday/Thursday dance. Our passes allow flexible combinations.
cuerpofitFaqQ10: How long until I see results?
cuerpofitFaqA10: 2-4 weeks: you'll notice better body control and less fatigue in dance class. 1-2 months: visible improvement in strength and endurance. 3-6 months: significant performance transformation. Consistency is key: minimum 1 weekly class.
cuerpofitFaqQ11: Do I need to be in good shape to start?
cuerpofitFaqA11: No. The class is adaptable to all levels. Each exercise has variations from beginner to advanced. Cris guides you according to your current level. Many students started without doing any exercise and are now in their best shape ever.
cuerpofitFaqQ12: Is it good for back pain?
cuerpofitFaqA12: Yes, strengthening core and glutes significantly reduces lower back pain. 70% of students with chronic lumbar pain report improvement in the first 4-6 weeks. If you have an active injury, consult with your doctor first.
cuerpofitFaqA13: Cris Ag, specialist in physical conditioning for dancers, trained in the Farray Method¬Æ. She also teaches stretching and glute workout classes. Her approach combines anatomical knowledge with practical dance experience.
cuerpofitFaqQ14: What's the difference from going to the gym?
cuerpofitFaqA14: At the gym you work isolated muscles with machines. In body conditioning you work functional movement patterns with your own body. The exercises are designed to transfer directly to dance: extensions, turns, jumps, direction changes.
cuerpofitFaqQ15: Where is the academy and how can I contact you?
cuerpofitFaqA15: Farray's Center is at Calle Enten√ßa 100, Barcelona (between Plaza Espa√±a and Sants). Metro: L1/L3 Espanya, L5 Sants Estaci√≥. Body conditioning classes: Mondays 7:00-8:00pm. Contact: WhatsApp or email through our website.

fullBodyCardioWhatIsTitle: What is Cuerpo-Fit and why does it work?
fullBodyCardioWhatIsP1: Cuerpo-Fit is the workout that changes the fitness game in Barcelona. Imagine combining the intensity of full body training with the energy of cardio dance, all in 60 minutes that fly by. It's not a gym. It's not a conventional dance class. It's the best of both worlds.
fullBodyCardioWhatIsP2: Born from the physical conditioning used by our academy's professional dancers, we've adapted their techniques so anyone‚Äîregardless of their level‚Äîcan benefit. The result: a stronger, more agile and more toned body, without the monotony of machines.
fullBodyCardioWhatIsP3: Each session is designed to work your entire body: legs, glutes, core, arms and back. But here's the trick: we do it to the rhythm of music, with functional exercises that mimic dance movements. You burn between 400 and 500 calories without realizing you're training.
fullBodyCardioWhatIsP4: Cuerpo-Fit is for you if the gym bores you, if you want real results without suffering, or if you're simply looking for a fun way to get fit. Zero previous experience needed. Just the desire to move.

fullBodyCardioFaqQ1: How many calories do you burn in Cuerpo-Fit?
fullBodyCardioFaqA1: En una session for Cuerpo-Fit de 60 minutos se queman aproximadamente 400-500 calories, dependiendo de tu peso e intensidad. Es equivalente a 45 minutos de running, but much more fun and with less impact on the joints. The combined work of cardio and toning keeps your metabolism active even after class (EPOC effect).
fullBodyCardioFaqQ2: Do I need to know how to dance to do Cuerpo-Fit?
fullBodyCardioFaqA2: No. Cuerpo-Fit is not a dance class, it's functional training with music. The movements are fitness exercises (squats, lunges, core...) sequenced to the rhythm of music. There are no choreographies to memorize. If you can walk, you can do Cuerpo-Fit.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ3: What's the difference between Cuerpo-Fit and the gym?
fullBodyCardioFaqA3: Cuerpo-Fit: group training with music, functional exercises, without machines, guaranteed fun, adapted in real time. Gym: isolated machines, monotonous repetitions, without guidance (usually). Same caloric expenditure, but Cuerpo-Fit has better adherence because it's not boring.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ4: What clothes should I wear to Cuerpo-Fit?
fullBodyCardioFaqA4: Required clothing: ropa deportiva c√≥moda (leggings, camiseta transpirable), zapatillas de deporte. Recomendado: toalla peque√±a, botella de agua. No necesitas: special dance clothes or extra equipment (we provide everything).
fullBodyCardioFaqQ5: Is it suitable for absolute beginners?
fullBodyCardioFaqA5: S√≠, 100%. Cuerpo-Fit is open level designed for everyone. Each exercise has 3 intensity levels: bajo (principiantes), medio (intermedios), alto (avanzados). T√∫ eliges en cada momento. Cris adapts and corrects in real time. Many of our students started without having set foot in a gym in years.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ6: How often should I do Cuerpo-Fit to see results?
fullBodyCardioFaqA6: Con 1 weekly class ya notar√°s cambios en energ√≠a y √°nimo. For visible toning results, we recommend 2 sesiones semanales (you can combine with other classes at the academy). La constancia es m√°s importante que the intensity. Better 1 class each week for months than 5 classes one week and then nothing.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ7: Can I do Cuerpo-Fit if I'm overweight?
fullBodyCardioFaqA7: S√≠. Cuerpo-Fit is especially effective for people who want to lose weight because: it works the whole body (more caloric expenditure), the exercises are low impact (they take care of the joints), and each movement has lower intensity variations. Many students with excess weight choose Cuerpo-Fit precisely because they don't feel judged and can go at their own pace.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ8: What muscles do I work in Cuerpo-Fit?
fullBodyCardioFaqA8: Cuerpo-Fit es full body, works all major muscle groups: Tren inferior: cu√°driceps, isquiotibiales, gl√∫teos, gemelos. Core: abdominales, oblicuos, espalda baja. Tren superior: arms, shoulders, back, chest. En 60 minutos activamos m√°s del 60% de tu masa muscular total.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ9: How long does it take to see results?
fullBodyCardioFaqA9: Semanas 1-2: m√°s energ√≠a, mejor humor, mejor sue√±o. Semanas 3-4: clothes start to fit differently, more strength in daily activities. Meses 1-2: cambios visibles en tonificaci√≥n, resistencia cardiovascular mejorada. Mes 3+: transformation notable, nuevos h√°bitos consolidados. Resultados with practice regular de 1-2 times per week.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ10: ¬øHay classes for Cuerpo-Fit for mayores de 40 o 50 years?
fullBodyCardioFaqA10: S√≠, tenemos alumnos de todas las edades, desde 20 to 60+ years. Cuerpo-Fit is especially recommended for people over 40 because: it maintains muscle mass (which starts to be lost with age), improves bone density, is low impact (takes care of joints), and each exercise adapts to your level. Age is not an excuse, it's a reason to start.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ11: ¬øC√≥mo es una class t√≠pica for Cuerpo-Fit?
fullBodyCardioFaqA11: Calentamiento (10 min): activaci√≥n cardiovascular suave, movilidad articular. Bloque principal (40 min): circuitos de full body exercises al ritmo de la music, combinando cardio y tonificaci√≥n, with pausas activas. Vuelta a la calma (10 min): estiramientos, respiraci√≥n, relajaci√≥n. All guided by Cris with motivating music in the background.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ12: What intensity level does the class have?
fullBodyCardioFaqA12: Intensidad moderada-alta, pero siempre adaptable. Cuerpo-Fit works with the principle of "choose your intensity": cada ejercicio tiene versi√≥n suave (principiantes), media (intermedios) e intensa (avanzados). T√∫ decides en cada momento cu√°nto das. La idea es que termines sudando pero sonriendo, no arrastr√°ndote.
fullBodyCardioFaqQ13: Can I do Cuerpo-Fit if I have injuries?
fullBodyCardioFaqA13: Depende de la lesi√≥n. Requisitos: consult with your doctor or physiotherapist first. If you have medical clearance, let us know before class to adapt exercises. Contraindicaciones absolutas: lesiones agudas, problemas card√≠acos no controlados, embarazo de riesgo. Cris can modify exercises for most common limitations (knees, back, shoulders).

kpopWhatIsP2: In Barcelona, K-Pop Dance has exploded thanks to groups like BTS, BLACKPINK, Stray Kids, TWICE, and aespa. It's not just about imitating moves: it's technique, expression, musicality, and connection with a global community of fans who share the same passion.

kpopCulturalHistoryTitle: Want to learn more about K-Pop Dance?
kpopCulturalShort: K-Pop Dance is the dance style associated with Korean pop, characterized by synchronized, precise, and visually stunning choreographies. Born in South Korea in the 90s, it fuses hip hop, jazz, contemporary, and urban styles. In Barcelona, Farray's International Dance Center has been a reference in urban dance teaching since 2012.
kpopCulturalFull:
### Definition: What is K-Pop Dance?

**K-Pop Dance is the dance style that accompanies Korean pop music (Korean Pop), characterized by synchronized, precise, and visually stunning choreographies.** Although K-Pop as a musical genre has its roots in the 1990s with pioneering groups like Seo Taiji and Boys (1992), the dance style has evolved enormously, fusing elements of American hip hop, jazz, contemporary, vogueing, and urban styles.

### The Origins: From Seoul to the World

The debut of Seo Taiji and Boys on April 11, 1992, on Korean television is considered the starting point of modern K-Pop. Their fusion of American hip hop with Korean sensibilities had a significant impact on the Asian music industry. From there, Korean entertainment agencies (SM, YG, JYP, HYBE) developed a rigorous training system that includes years of practice in singing, dancing, languages, and performance.

### The Golden Era: 2010-present

K-Pop achieved worldwide recognition with groups like **BTS** (2013), **BLACKPINK** (2016), **Stray Kids** (2018), **TWICE** (2015), **aespa** (2020), and **NewJeans** (2022). BTS became the first K-Pop group to top the Billboard Hot 100 with "Dynamite" (2020), while BLACKPINK accumulated YouTube view records.

### Technical Elements of K-Pop Dance

- **Group synchronization**: Multiple dancers executing identical movements with millimetric precision
- **Point moves**: Iconic movements designed to be recognizable and viral
- **Facial expression**: Fundamental in K-Pop; idols train to convey specific emotions during each song
- **Formations**: Complex position changes that create visual patterns from the viewer's perspective
- **Style versatility**: A single song can combine hip hop, contemporary, and voguing sections

### Benefits of K-Pop Dance

- **Physical fitness**: K-Pop choreographies are physically demanding and provide a complete cardiovascular workout
- **Coordination and memory**: Learning complex sequences improves muscular and cognitive memory
- **Artistic expression**: Combines technique with emotional interpretation
- **Community**: K-Pop has a highly engaged global fan community
- **Mental health**: Regular dance practice can help reduce stress and improve mood

### The Phenomenon in Barcelona

Barcelona has a constantly growing K-Pop community, with regular events, cover competitions, and an active scene of fans and dancers. Random dance plays (events where choreographies are danced randomly in public spaces) attract numerous participants at various locations throughout the city.

### K-Pop Dance at Farray's Center

**Farray's International Dance Center**, located at **Calle Enten√ßa 100, Eixample district, Barcelona**, is a CID UNESCO recognized academy offering training in multiple urban styles. With over 15,000 students trained since 2012 and a 4.9/5 rating on Google with over 500 reviews, the academy combines professionalism with a family-friendly and inclusive environment.

**Academy details:**
- **Address:** Calle Enten√ßa 100, 08015 Barcelona
- **Access:** Metro L1/L3 (Pla√ßa Espanya), L5 (Enten√ßa), Rodalies (Barcelona-Sants)
- **Facilities:** +700 m¬≤, rooms with mirrors, professional sound, air conditioning

kpopFaqTitle: Frequently Asked Questions about K-Pop Dance in Barcelona
kpopFaqQ1: Do I need previous experience to start K-Pop classes?
kpopFaqA1: No. Our K-Pop classes are designed for all levels. If you've never danced, you'll start at the beginner level where you'll learn the fundamentals step by step. The important thing is to be eager to learn and enjoy.
kpopFaqQ2: Which K-Pop groups are danced in the classes?
kpopFaqA2: We work on choreographies from the most popular groups: BTS, BLACKPINK, Stray Kids, TWICE, aespa, NewJeans, ITZY, TXT, (G)I-DLE, SEVENTEEN, and more. The choreos are updated with new releases.

commercialCulturalHistoryTitle: Want to know more about Commercial Dance?
commercialCulturalShort: Commercial Dance was born in 1983 with Michael Jackson's music videos and has become the dominant style in the music industry. It fuses hip hop, jazz funk, contemporary, and heels. In Barcelona, Farray's International Dance Center has been teaching commercial styles since 2012, training dancers for the entertainment industry.
commercialCulturalFull:
### What exactly is Commercial Dance?

**Commercial Dance is the dance style you see in music videos, concerts, TV commercials, and live shows.** It's also known as "Industry Dance" or "Video Dance." Unlike freestyle or hip hop battles, Commercial is choreographed specifically for recordings and major productions.

What sets Commercial apart from other styles is its **versatility**: it mixes hip hop, jazz, contemporary, heels, and any technique that works for the song or artist. It doesn't have a fixed "syllabus" like ballet. It's chameleon-like and constantly evolves with trends.

### 1983: The year that changed everything

While dance has always existed in entertainment, **1983 was the year modern Commercial Dance was born**. That year, Michael Jackson released the music videos for "Beat It" and "Thriller," choreographed by Michael Peters and Vincent Paterson.

For the first time, millions of people worldwide saw synchronized choreography with formations, fusing urban styles with theatrical technique. MTV had just been born (1981) and these videos proved that dance could be as much of a star as the music.

### The pioneers who defined the style

In the 80s and 90s, four choreographers laid the foundation for what we know today:

- **Vincent Paterson**: Choreographed "Smooth Criminal" and "Bad" by Michael Jackson, plus Madonna shows.
- **Paula Abdul**: Went from being a Lakers cheerleader to defining the aesthetic of 80s-90s music videos.
- **Tina Landon**: Her work with Janet Jackson on "Rhythm Nation" and "If" defined an era.
- **Fatima Robinson**: Innovated with Aaliyah, Michael Jackson, and the Backstreet Boys.

### The golden era: 90s-2000s

Choreographers like Laurieann Gibson, Dave Scott, and Brian Friedman took Commercial to its peak with artists like Britney Spears, Christina Aguilera, Usher, and Destiny's Child. The style was characterized by:

- Clean, precise, powerful movements
- Complex formations and dynamic changes
- Intense facial expression that connects with the camera
- Style fusion according to the artist's needs

### Commercial Dance today (2024-2025)

The industry has evolved enormously. These are some of the choreographers defining the current visual sound:

**Parris Goebel** (New Zealand): Creator of the "polyswagg" style, she has worked with Rihanna, Justin Bieber ("Sorry"), and Jennifer Lopez. In 2024, she choreographed Doja Cat's historic Coachella show (first female rapper to headline) and Lady Gaga's "Disease" music video. In 2025, she co-directed and choreographed Lady Gaga's "Abracadabra" and her Coachella + Mayhem Ball Tour. She was also artistic director and choreographer of Vogue World Paris 2024.

**JaQuel Knight** (USA): Creator of Beyonc√©'s iconic "Single Ladies" dance. He made history in 2020 by becoming the first choreographer to copyright his choreography. In 2024, he made his Broadway debut choreographing "The Wiz" revival and directed Chris Stapleton's "Think I'm in Love with You" music video.

**Sean Bankhead** (USA): Danced with Usher at Super Bowl LVIII (2024). His choreographies include "Industry Baby" by Lil Nas X, "Motivation" and "Wild Side" by Normani, "2 Hands" and "It's Ok I'm Ok" by Tate McRae, "Rockstar" and "New Woman" by Lisa (BLACKPINK), and "On My Mama" by Victoria Mon√©t. Choreographer for the 2024 MTV VMAs (Lisa and GloRilla).

K-Pop has also transformed Commercial Dance into a global industry, with choreographers from Korea, the US, and Europe constantly collaborating.

### What do you work on in Commercial Dance?

- **Camera presence**: Knowing which angles flatter you and how to express with your gaze
- **Isolations**: Precise body control, moving one body part while the rest stays still
- **Grooves**: The rhythmic foundation of hip hop that gives movement its "flavor"
- **Performance quality**: That extra energy that brings choreography to life
- **Versatility**: Ability to adapt to different musical genres and choreographic styles

### Commercial Dance in Barcelona

**Farray's International Dance Center**, in the **Eixample district (Calle Enten√ßa 100, between Plaza Espa√±a and Sants)**, is one of Barcelona's reference academies for commercial styles.

Recognized by CID UNESCO and directed by Yunaisy Farray (actress in Street Dance 2), the academy has been training dancers since 2012 with over 25 styles available. With a 4.9/5 Google rating and over 15,000 students trained, it combines professionalism with a welcoming, inclusive atmosphere.

kizombaWhatIsTitle: What is Kizomba and why is everyone talking about it?
kizombaWhatIsP1: Imagine a dance where the connection with your partner is so intense it feels like you're reading each other's minds. Where every movement comes from the embrace, not memorized steps. That's Kizomba: the most sensual dance from Africa, born in Angola in the late 80s and now conquering dance floors worldwide.
kizombaWhatIsP2: Kizomba was born from the fusion of Angolan Semba with Zouk from the French Antilles. The name means "party" in Kimbundu, one of the Bantu languages of Angola. Unlike other Latin dances, Kizomba is danced in a close embrace with undulating hip movements, where the leader guides with the torso, not the hands.

kizombaCulturalHistoryTitle: Want to know the history of Kizomba?
kizombaCulturalShort: Kizomba was born in Angola in the late 1980s, fusing traditional Semba with Antillean Zouk. From Luanda it spread to Portugal, France, and today is one of the most popular partner dances worldwide. At Farray's Center we teach authentic Kizomba with respect for its African roots.
kizombaCulturalFull:
### Where does Kizomba come from?

**Kizomba was born in Angola in the late 1980s**, primarily in Luanda, the capital. The name comes from Kimbundu, a Bantu language, and means "party" or "celebration." It emerged when Angolan musicians began fusing **Semba** (Angola's traditional dance) with the electronic rhythms of **Zouk** from the French Antilles.

### Semba: the root of everything

Before Kizomba, there was Semba, an Angolan partner dance characterized by quick hip movements and a close embrace. Semba has centuries of history and is considered one of the origins of Brazilian samba (when Angolan slaves were taken to Brazil).

Kizomba took the embrace and connection from Semba, but slowed it down and added the sensuality of Zouk music, creating something completely new.

### Eduardo Paim and the pioneers

**Eduardo Paim** is considered the father of modern Kizomba. In 1981, he began experimenting by fusing Semba with electronic rhythms. Other fundamental artists were:

- **Bibi dos Santos**: Composer and producer who defined the classic sound
- **Paulo Flores**: Brought Kizomba to new audiences
- **Bonga**: Though better known for Semba, influenced the style's evolution

### The expansion to Europe

In the 1990s, with Angola's independence and migrations, Kizomba arrived in **Portugal**, where it found a second home. Lisbon became the European epicenter of the dance. From there it spread to France, Spain, Germany, and the rest of the world.

Today there are Kizomba festivals in more than 50 countries. In Barcelona, the scene has grown enormously in the last decade.

### Styles within Kizomba

With globalization, Kizomba has evolved into several styles:

- **Traditional Kizomba**: The original Angolan style, with emphasis on connection and musicality
- **Urban Kiz**: A more modern version with hip hop influences and more technical movements
- **Tarraxinha**: A slower, more sensual style, focused on hip movements
- **Ghetto Zouk**: Fusion of Kizomba with R&B and Zouk, popular at parties

### What is worked on in Kizomba classes?

- **Embrace and connection**: The foundation of everything. Learning to lead and follow from the torso
- **Ginga**: The basic hip movement characteristic of the style
- **Musicality**: Interpreting the different instruments and layers of the music
- **Sa√≠das**: Figures and exits that add variety without losing connection
- **Tarraxinha**: The slower, more sensual undulating movements

### Kizomba in Barcelona

**Farray's International Dance Center**, in the **Eixample district (Calle Enten√ßa 100, between Plaza Espa√±a and Sants)**, offers Kizomba classes focused on authentic connection and respect for the African roots of the dance.

Recognized by CID UNESCO and with more than 15,000 students trained, the academy combines professional technique with a welcoming atmosphere where you can truly learn to dance Kizomba.

kizombaFaqTitle: Frequently Asked Questions about Kizomba in Barcelona
kizombaFaqQ1: Do I need previous experience to start Kizomba?
kizombaFaqA1: No. Our beginner classes are designed for absolute beginners. You'll start from the basic embrace and connection.
kizombaFaqQ2: Can I come without a dance partner?
kizombaFaqA2: Yes. Many students come alone and we rotate partners during class. It's an excellent way to meet people and improve your adaptability.
kizombaFaqQ3: What's the difference between Kizomba and bachata?
kizombaFaqA3: Kizomba is slower and with a closer embrace. It comes from Angola (Africa), while bachata is Dominican (Caribbean). Kizomba emphasizes connection and undulations; bachata has more lateral steps and turns.
kizombaFaqQ4: What should I wear to classes?
kizombaFaqA4: Comfortable clothes that allow you to move freely. Shoes with smooth soles (not chunky sneakers). Ladies can wear low heels or socks.
kizombaFaqQ5: Is Kizomba very sensual? Is it appropriate for everyone?
kizombaFaqA5: Kizomba is sensual but always respectful. In class we work on technical connection and mutual respect. You decide the level of intimacy with your partner.
kizombaFaqQ6: Are there different styles of Kizomba?
kizombaFaqA6: Yes. There's traditional Kizomba (Angolan), Urban Kiz (more modern), Tarraxinha (slower and more sensual) and Ghetto Zouk (fusion with R&B).
kizombaFaqQ7: Can I try a class before signing up?
kizombaFaqA7: Yes. We offer a welcome class at a special price so you can try without commitment.
kizombaFaqQ8: What type of music is used in Kizomba?
kizombaFaqA8: Kizomba music (artists like Nelson Freitas, Mika Mendes, C4 Pedro), Ghetto Zouk, and R&B remixes. Slow rhythms with African and Antillean influence.
kizombaFaqA9: Yes. Although it's a slow dance, you work your core, legs, balance and coordination. It also reduces stress thanks to the connection and embrace.
kizombaFaqQ10: How long does it take to learn?
kizombaFaqA10: In 2-3 months of regular classes you can dance comfortably at parties. Kizomba has an accessible learning curve compared to other dances.
kizombaFaqA11: Farray's Center is at Calle Enten√ßa 100, 08015 Barcelona, 5 minutes from Plaza Espa√±a and Sants. Excellent metro, bus and train connections.
kizombaFaqQ12: Do you organize Kizomba parties or practice sessions?
kizombaFaqA12: Yes. We organize socials and practice sessions where you can dance what you've learned in a relaxed atmosphere.
kizombaFaqQ13: Can I combine Kizomba with other styles?
kizombaFaqA13: Absolutely. Kizomba perfectly complements bachata, salsa and zouk. Many dancers study several styles.
kizombaFaqQ14: Is Kizomba suitable for all ages?
kizombaFaqA14: Yes. We have students from young to over 60. Being a dance without jumps or sudden movements, it's accessible to everyone.
kizombaFaqQ15: How can I contact you for more information?
kizombaFaqA15:
